comment._content: "Goold's Cross was once the junction for the short branch line to the well known town of Cashel, which diverged just south of the station." eiretrains.com/Photo_Gallery/Railway%20Stations%20G/Goold... "Railway in course of construction" is shown just south of Goolds Cross Station. maps.osi.ie/publicviewer/#V1,602848,648187,7,9

comment._content: The station seems to have been operational by 1855, unfortunately for the the reverend gentleman Freeman's Journal and Daily Commercial Advertiser, Wednesday, January 24, 1855

comment.author: 14302637@N08
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/nlireland] The very interesting Cashel Railway website says "ceremoniously dug the first sod at Gouldscross on March 4, 1903" and "the opening of the Cashel branch line on Monday, December 19, 1904." There is a photo of the corrugated iron station at Cashel. www.seamusjking.com/Articles%20Full/cashel_railway.html This particular map sheet could have been surveyed in 1903. It looks like 25 inch to the mile, or 1:2500. Sometimes older maps were overprinted when new railways were surveyed. When zooming out there are 2 earlier editions underneath. Aerial views show that the railway has been completely ploughed out near Goolds Cross. Nearer to Cashel it can be traced through the fields, terminating at what is now a factory. maps.osi.ie/publicviewer/#V1,606917,641070,6,0

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/blackpoolbeach] Very interesting, as you say. Now I'm wondering how first sods being dug in 1903 ties in with [http://www.flickr.com/photos/johnspooner]'s snippet from the Freeman's Journal above. What other kind of station would have been at Goold's/Gould's Cross in 1855?
comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons

comment.author: 14302637@N08
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/nlireland] "Goolds Cross & Cashel" was on the Great Southern and Western Railway 1902 map between Thurles and Limerick Junction. It would have been the nearest station to Cashel before the branch line was opened in 1904. upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/c/c9/Great_Souther...

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/blackpoolbeach] Thank you! So the case of the Revd. Robert Armstrong becomes curiouser and curiouser...
comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons

comment.author: 90823939@N04
comment._content: Alby started as a boy porter in Dundrum Co Tipperary and ended his railway career as Regional Area Inspector For the Limerick Region. Died 2011. RIP.

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/90823939@N04] Thanks very much! Lovely to have "Alby" as his name, and sorry to hear he died so recently.
comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons

comment.author: 90823939@N04
comment._content: The station at Gooldscross opened to passengers in July 1848, and became a junction for The Cashel Branch when the Cashel Extension Railway opened in 1904. The station sign at Gooldscross stated "GOOLDSCROSS" and directly underneath this was "CHANGE FOR CASHEL AND ROCKWELL COLLEGE"  I have an old photograph of the sign.

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/90823939@N04] Thanks for the extra information, Billy. You should pop that photograph up on your photostream.
comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons
